RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



WICKLIFFE PAPER COMPANY - WICKLIFFE, KY



The Wickliffe Paper Company referred to hereafter as the Wickliffe Mill operates a pulp and paper mill located in Wickliffe, Kentucky.  The Wickliffe Mill is a subsidiary of the NewPage Corporation with headquarters located in Miamisburg, Ohio, and core business consisting of manufacturing coated and uncoated paper.  The NewPage Corporation and the Wickliffe Mill are committed to conducting operations in a manner that protects the safety of our employees, the public, and the environment.   



To achieve this commitment, the Wickliffe Mill has established detailed policies, procedures, and work practices as part of our environmental, health, and safety (EHS) management system.  One component of our management system is a Risk Management Plan (RMP) which assists in identifying and minimizing our risks and is intended comply with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) regulation found in 40 CFR Part 68, "Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.  The intent of the remaining sections of this document is to provide a summary of the elements contained in the Wickliffe Mill's risk management plan.   





Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:



NewPage Corporation is committed to the safety of its workers, contractors and the public, and the preservation of the environment, through the prevention any of accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The Wickliffe Mill has systems in place that provide reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  At the core of our prevention program are policies and work practices for employee and contractor training; procedures for proper operation and maintenance; pre-job planning and hazard assessments; audits and inspections; engineering design and control specifications; and procedures for evaluating process modifications.   Additionally, the mill has established nume

rous environmental and safety policies to ensure the safety and well being of our employees, minimize potential impacts to the environment and maintain regulatory compliance.



In the event of an accidental release, the Wickliffe Mill has trained personnel to assess, control, and contain the release in a manner that will reduce the risk of exposure to employees, the public, and the environment.  The Wickliffe Mill has more than 100 emergency responders trained in dealing with releases of materials specific to our mill operations.  A written emergency response plan contains a formal incident command system to allow a structured and efficient response to mill emergencies.  On-site materials and response activities have been reviewed with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the State Disaster and Emergency Response Coordinator.  The Mill conducts periodic training exercises to maintain our readiness to respond to potential releases.  



Wickliffe Mill and Regulated Substances:



The Wickliffe Mill is an integrated pulp and paper mill that manufactures bleached pulp and coated and uncoated paper.  As part of our operation, the Wickliffe Mill manufactures and/or uses two chemical substances that are subject to the reporting requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.  The first regulated chemical substance is chlorine.  The mill withdraws water from the Mississippi River and pumps it to our filter plant for raw water treatment.  Chlorine is used to disinfect the raw water prior to its distribution into the mill.  The second regulated substance is chlorine dioxide.  Chlorine dioxide is manufactured on-site and is used in the whitening of pulp in the pulp mill operating unit.     





Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention:



The Wickliffe Mill continually evaluates ways to prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances.  In 1994, the Wickliffe Mill implemented the 14 elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The EPA

RMP rule, published in 1996, established various levels of prevention program requirements.  Both the chlorine at the raw water filter plant and the chlorine dioxide at the pulp mill are Program 3 level processes.  This program level is similar to OSHA's PSM program, except that the RMP program focuses on protecting the public and the environment.  A prevention program to meet these requirements has been developed for both the chlorine and chlorine dioxide processes.  The prevention program is comprised of the following 12 elements:



 - Process safety information

 - Pre-startup review

 - Process hazard analysis

 - Compliance audit

 - Operating procedures

 - Incident investigation

 - Training

 - Employee participation

 - Mechanical integrity

 - Hot work permits

 - Management of change

 - Contractors



In addition to the required prevention program elements, the Wickliffe Mill has implemented safety features specific to the hazardous substances used at our mill.  Chlorine is supplied to the mill in Department of Transportation (DOT) approved one ton cylinders.  Chlorine is fed through a short section of piping to a mixer where it is safely absorbed into the mill's raw water feed.  The entire feed system is operated under a vacuum.  If the vacuum is lost, the cylinder valve will close automatically.  The materials of construction and the delivery system all meet the specifications of the suppliers.  Chlorine detectors are located throughout the areas where chlorine is present in the raw water filter plant.  These alarms are set to trigger below a concentration that would be dangerous to the operator.  The alarms are audible within the chlorine area and also alarm in the power center control room where displays are constantly monitored.  



Chlorine dioxide is generated on-site in a state of the art computer controlled process.  The dilute solution in water is stored in one tank and fed to the process through pumps and piping dedicated for chlorine dioxid

e service.  The materials of construction and delivery system all meet the specifications of the suppliers and general industry standards.  Chlorine/chlorine dioxide detectors are located throughout the areas where chlorine dioxide is present in the pulp mill process areas.  These alarms are set to trigger below a concentration that would be dangerous to the operator.  The alarms are audible within the chlorine area and also alarm in the pulp mill control room where displays are constantly monitored.  





Five Year Accident History:



There were no reportable accidents in the last five years involving our RMP covered processes.  The last accident associated with one of the regulated substances occurred in August 1999.





Emergency Response Program:



The Wickliffe Mill has developed a written emergency response program centered on the mill's emergency disaster plan to help make the appropriate response to accidental releases of hazardous substances.  The program includes information specific to both processes at the mill.  The information includes:



- Evaluation of the accidental release, determination of evacuation and emergency response support, notification to appropriate public agencies and management personnel.

- Controlling and containing accidental releases, including the use of emergency response equipment and the inspection, testing, and maintenance of that equipment.

- Providing first aid and emergency medical treatment for accidental exposure to hazardous substances.

- Training for employees in relevant procedures.

- Procedures to review and update the emergency response program and update employees as necessary.



The Wickliffe Mill maintains an emergency response team of more than 100 members.  All workers, contractors, and visitors are trained in appropriate evacuation procedures.  The mill routinely conducts emergency response training and drills and each mill area conducts periodic evacuation drills.



The Wickliffe Mill emergency respo

nse plan complies with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.38(a) as required by the Process Safety Management rule and has been communicated to local responders.  Information has been supplied to local responders as part of the "TAB Q-7" of the county emergency operations plan for the Wickliffe Mill.  Additionally, the Wickliffe Mill has employees that actively participate on our Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and volunteer on the local fire and rescue squads in our community.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



The Wickliffe Mill continually strives to improve the safety of processes at the mill.  The chlorine and chlorine dioxide process safety is evaluated through a periodic review of the respective hazard and operability studies (HAZOP), management of change procedures, incident investigation programs, safety action teams, solicitation of safety suggestions from employees, and through best practices shared within our industrial sector.  Presently, no significant modifications to either regulated process are planned.
